comment_text: When he was talking about continuity, I was reminded of his video on limits

Since music maps to a binary tree, there is already an extremely advanced human intuition for mapping a space filling curve, but since music relates discontinuous events (i.e events that are a beat, a measure or a phrase apart) the idea of 'continuity' is different.  Not knowing about the hilbert curve, I developed a curve that, while discontinuous, does map like events in musical space to like events in physical space, in a way that maybe only has the advantage of being easier to intuit for a human, because it doesn't require rotation of the curve from one order to the next.  At any scale, the traversal is upper left, upper right, lower left, lower right.  There is a discontinuity in the middle of each set of 4, but since humans are used to musical patterns of powers of two, it's a pretty intuitive mapping.  And if you thread the discontinuity through the 'in between' space, you get a properly continuous curve that visually divides space into 4 at every scale.   And although it only maps to positive points, you don't need to resort to the 'cheat' of spiraling in order to keep filling positive space.  I used it to create a kind of music paper that I used for many years, and made it very easy to keep track of where you were in the music.  It obviously works better for music that is more binary (or quaternary) such as folk or pop, and less well for more through-composed music.  I never did figure out the math to describe it though...

I used to work with geographic information systems, and the Hilbert R-tree is an absolutely essential tool for arranging items in 2D into a 1D space (the computer memory). You'd want adjacent coordinates in 2D space to be close to each other in your 1D array as well, since it helps with locality-sensitive querying, caching and prefetching, thus increasing performance. The Hilbert curve has this nice property, so it's used as a way to assign a linear ordering to your data.

I actually used the hilbert curve once in some software i wrote. i needed an algorithm that could traverse every point in a grid of unknown size. i considered the zamboni method, but realized that doesn't work if you don't know any side lengths of your grid. there are probably other solutions, but i realized the hilbert curve doesn't need a side length to fill a square grid. you can just start drawing it until you hit a wall. once you hit a wall, you've filled the grid entirely. i had my algorithm walk the hilbert curve as a path until it hit a wall, and in doing so it traversed every cell in the grid. i never though i'd actually use the hilbert curve for something other than doodling, but there you go lol

We can prove that we can map [0,1] to the unit square [0,1]×[0,1] by verifying that they have the same cardinality. An equivalent statement to the axiom of choice is that all infinite sets have the same cardinality as the Cartesian product with themselves, A.K.A. their Cartesian square. Since [0,1] and [0,1]² have the same cardinality, there must be a bijection from one set to the other. Now, such a mapping need not be continuous however.

Let $p$ be the minimum value allowed by the piecewise definition of the current case, and $q$ be the maximum value.

Let $t^{\ast}=\frac{t-p}{q-p}\Leftarrow p\le t\le q$

The formula for the Hilbert Curve is $h_{\infty}$ where:

$h_n\left(t\right)=\left\{\begin{matrix}\left\{\begin{matrix}\left(\frac{1}{4} ,\frac{3t}{2}+\frac{1}{4}\right)&\Leftarrow&t\le\frac{1}{3}\\\left(\frac{3t}{2}+\frac{1}{4},\frac{3}{4}\right)&\Leftarrow&\frac{1}{3}\le t\le\frac{2}{3}\\\left(\frac{3}{4},\frac{3}{4}-\frac{3t}{2}\right)&\Leftarrow&t\le\frac{2}{3}\end{matrix}\right\}&\Leftarrow&n=1\\\left\{\begin{matrix}\left(\frac{h^y_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2},\frac{h^x_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2}\right)&\Leftarrow&t\le\frac{4^{n-1}-1}{4^n-1}\\\left(2^{-n},\frac{1}{2}-2^{-n-1}+2^nt^{\ast}\right)&\Leftarrow&\frac{4^{n-1}-1}{4^n-1}\le t\le\frac{4^{n-1}}{4^n-1}\\\left(\frac{h^x_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2},\frac{1}{2}+\frac{h^y_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2}\right)&\Leftarrow&\frac{4^{n-1}}{4^n-1}\le t\le\frac{2\times4^{n-1}-1}{4^n-1}\\\left(\frac{1}{2}-2^{-n-1}+2^nt^{\ast},\frac{1}{2}+2^{-n}\right)&\Leftarrow&\frac{2\times4^{n-1}-1}{4^n-1}\le t\le\frac{2\times4^{n-1}}{4^n-1}\\\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{h^x_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2},\frac{1}{2}+\frac{h^y_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2}\right)&\Leftarrow&\frac{2\times4^{n-1}}{4^n-1}\le t\le\frac{3\times4^{n-1}-1}{4^n-1}\\\left(1-2^{-n},-\frac{1}{2}-2^{-n-1}+2^nt^{\ast}\right)&\Leftarrow&\frac{3\times4^{n-1}-1}{4^n-1}\le t\le\frac{3\times4^{n-1}}{4^n-1}\\\left(1-\frac{h^y_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2},\frac{1}{2}-\frac{h^x_{n-1}\left(t^{\ast}\right)}{2}\right)&\Leftarrow&t\ge\frac{3\times4^{n-1}}{4^n-1}\end{matrix}\right\}&\Leftarrow&n>1\end{matrix}\right\}$

Not that I want to ruin the party, but... these space-filling curves are very nice, but they are built on assumptions about geometry that don't quite hold. There isn't really anything that says that real numbers should be used in modelling the continuity of a line or curve, especially since we now have a theory of infinitesimals in function. Cantor didn't believe in infinitesimals, and calculus strictly avoided their existence for a long time, but since Abraham Robinson proved they could be manipulated in a rigorous way, these numbers are indeed legit. This means that a more detailed model than the real numbers of the continuum is possible, one that deals with more precise points squeezed in between the rational points at new places. With a sufficiently strong microscope we can see these infinitesimals spread out around all the rational points infinitelly more numerous than the irrational numbers there, since points are considered as representing the same irrational number if there is only an infinitesimal length between them.

But there is still room for improvements. Since infinitesimal sizes exist in the continuum, we can also find infinitesimals to the infinitesimal size, infinitely smaller than the infinitesimal "1/ω" units, where ω = an infinite unit of size Aleph-null. And infinitesimals to the smaller infinitesimal units, and so on... Which tells us that the reciprocal of Cantor's infinities are as real as the real numbers, and should be regarded as such, especially if we try to map all the zero size points on a line segment, and using different numbers for points lying on different position, no matter how close.

I realize now I should also add an example, to enlighten the need for infinitesimals in the modelling of the continuum. Consider the Cantor set (a line segment that has its length reduced by a third in each of an infinite number of steps). The resulting length of what is left will be zero, using the standard methods of infinite series. Using instead "resulting length = starting length x (2/3)^H" where H is an infinite number, the result instead becomes an infinitesimal length bigger than zero. The infinitesimal length of the result depends on the infinite number H used, the bigger H the smaller the infinitesimal leftover becomes. Thanks to the standard methods disregard of infinitesimals we normally don't need to worry about them (they can often simply be ignored), but sometimes they play a main role, especially in exact calculations, or at least they should do.

Another example would be to introduce more precision in other infinite series calculations with the help of hyperreals. The series 1 + 1/2 + 1/4 + ... that has a real number sum of 2 then becomes the hyperreal 2 - 2 x (1/2)^ω, where ω is the infinite number of all positive integers. This hyperreal number is infinitesimally close to 2. Also divergent series are possible to calculate using hyperreals since they include infinite values, the diverging infinite series 1 + 3 + 5 + ... = ω^2. So, with more precision comes a better insight of standard math objects. The infinitely big and the infinitesimally small shouldn't be ignored like they used to be in the not so ancient math history. (see 'Hyperreal Numbers for Infinite Divergent Series')

To name a third example: What value has a point located infinitelly close and to the right of zero on the number line? This is a place with no rational or real precise value. It can only be identified as a positive infinitesimal value, and without it, you simply don't have a continuum, since there will be a jump over the infinitesimal points from the zero point to the finite positive points.

I think I learned something today that I have not known before, even though I disagree with David Hilbert, and contend that as long as this rests on the infinite divisibility of space, which is a beautiful unattainable concept, this too is unattainable. If you think about this carefully, you will discover that for such a curve to be constructed, it must imply that the perpendicular distance between any to parallel line segments on the curve must be zero. Otherwise there will be points between such parallel line segments not touch by the curve. Now if the perpendicular distance between parallel line segments is zero, it must follows that all line segments parallel to say the x-axis converge to one single line parallel to the x-axis. We therefore have an infinity of points above and below such a line. The same holds for the Y-axis. The conclusion is that we end up with an infinity of points that don't lie on any portion of the curve. Therefore the curve fails to touch each point of the  2D plane.

This video is well made, but it only shows that the concept of infinity which is used for limits is useful. There are other concepts of infinity from other areas of math for which it is much less obvious whether they are useful. An example for such an area is transfinite set theory where infinity is treated as a type of number.

Apart from questionable usefulness there are also quite a few paradoxes of infinity which suggest that the infinities of those areas even creates absurd results. For example the dartboard paradox or the Banach-Tarski paradox.

The fact that the space filling curve exists, is equivalent to saying that “size of a line segment” is the same as “size of a square”. “Size” here means cardinality, which is a distinct concept to volume when it comes to infinity. In fact, cardinalities of the line segment, the whole real line, a unit square, the whole 2D plane, and any higher dimension square and whole space, are all the same. And yes it means that there exists curve that can fill a 3D cube and higher dimensional cube.

The important property of a space filling curve, is that, it is not of bounded variation, which in English, it means even the input is between 0 and 1, the resulting curve has increasing length and is infinity at the limit. One can easily prove that any curve of bounded variation can never fill a higher dimension space.

Back to the original problem. What kind of function mapping a matrix to a vector would minimise the distance between all points? I.e. two points which have a low euclidean distance on the matrix should be close together in the vector? With a pseudo Hilbert curve two adjacent points on the matrix can be at opposite ends of the vector.

Curious notes : 1. There is a variant of the Hilbert Curve called a “Moore Curve” that joins up 4 rotates Hilbert Curves such that the ends connect to form a loop. Personally I think this is a more accurate way of connecting Cartesian space with frequency space. 2. The Morton Order Curve (aka z-order) can be made simply by taking the 2 coordinate numbers for x and y and interlacing then into a single number by combining their bits in the pattern xyxyxyxy (first number is xxxx bits, second number is yyyy, and the curve position number I s the combined pair.) To make a Hilbert Curve, you can do the same process if you treat the binary numbers as “Gray Code” numbers - kinda... It only works in some dimensions (4,8,24...) in other dimensions you need to do the flipping step on the bits... This is a reflection of deep properties relating to spatial packing.

While it is true that you can map 1D space in a way that any point in 2D space is approached infinitely closely, not every exact point in 2D space will have an exact counterpart on the [0,1] Interval. For example all points on the line that sepatarates the lower left quadrant from the lower right will never be ON the hilbert curve, only infinitely close to it. The exact midpoint (and we are really talking 0D point) of the square grid has 3 points on the [0,1] interval that get mapped ever closer to it. In binary representation those would be 0.001010... (1/8+1/32+1/128+...) , 0.1 (1/2) and 0.110101 (1-1/8-1/32-1/128...). In the practical application that would mean 3 very distinct frequencies describing almost the same point.

This is 2 years old, and very well done BTW, but I think there is a key element or limitation that wasn't highlighted. While the continuity of the mapping works well in one direction, it doesn't work well in the other direction even though it looks like it might.

That is, you could map from the 1D frequency space to the 2D image space nicely with stable convergence and so convert from sound to image very well. But, converting from image to sound doesn't behave as well. This is because neighbouring pixels can be at very different positions along the 1D line.

An easy example would be to shift the entire image left or right by 1 pixel. Even though the difference is almost imperceptible via our eyes, it would produce a sound profile nothimg like the original. This is most obvious at the pixels that cross the discontinuity on the middle bottom half of the image where pixels originally on the left of the "tear" are originally mapped to low frequency, but moved one pixel rightward puts them at the high frequencies.

Similar things happen with images taken with slightly different optical distortions from camera lena, or perspective changes such as moving twice as far with tice the zoom.

It is still great, interesting, and very useful, but could lead to some misunderdtandings about mapping across different dimentional spaces.

So results are stable and convergent for increasing resolution, and to content noise (being the image brightness/frequency amplitude in the example), but not positional measurement variations/errors/noise in thebimage space.

I'm curious if there are solutions around that, or if it is an inherent property of the change in dimentions, and if it carries to higher dimensional examples.

So in a very basic and perhaps insufficient understanding of the idea of turning a image into sound, the concept is that we are placing a set value for each pixel across a set of numbers (input,output) which associates with a resonating wavelength that is individual to all other resonating wavelengths in that image. If all wavelengths were put together we would get a single continuous wavelength that is distinct in sound to any other wavelength corresponding to a different image. We can increase the accuracy of the transcribed wavelength by increasing the total number of pixels AKA increasing the image's resolution. But if we only associate sound to a defined pixel it would be practically impossible for our brains to comprehend the sound of the image to effectively interpret the image without seeing it. Our brains can not intuitively interpret sight from sound. The image would give us a noise and we would have to elaborate on what that sound is corresponding to whether it is a elephant or perhaps a scenic image of a park in Japan. And no, hearing the wavelength of a respective pixel in a image is not the same as hearing a car driving by and stating affirmatively that is a car, because we can intuitively interpret the sound of the car to a image that directly corresponds with it not a bundle of pixels associated with the car.

One practical use for pseudo hilbert curves can be found in video game physics simulations, where one of the biggest problems is to find a fast method to bundle up objects of the game that are close to each other. Linearizing space by the use of pseudo hilbert curves allows 3D positions to be mapped to a 1D position on that curve, with the nice property that objects that are close to each other in 3D space also are close in this 1D mapping. When sorting a list of game object positions by the curve parameter one  can simply bundle close game objects by selecting specific segments in that list.

There is a problem with space-filling curves that leads to a paradox. Assume that the Cartesian plane maps to a line. Choose the x-axis as one line on the plane. There is an identical mapping between the points on the x-axis and your line. There is no space left on your line for any of the other points on the plane. Therefore, the plane does not map to the line.

This is another example of the axiom of choice (AoC) leading to a paradox. The assumption of the AoC is that you can select a point on the line that is mapped to by a given point on the plane. However, you cannot determine an algorithm to select that point, because while there is a function to map a point on the line to a point on the plane, there is no inverse function to map a point on the plane to a point on the line.

So a question, it seems to me that a Hilbert curve, while it can be defined, has no direction. In other words, take any point on the curve and try to figure out where "future" points will be. With a snake curve for example, every given point has a position and a direction (well one can give it a direction). If you are on the bottom left corner, no matter the resolution of the snake curve, you will always head to the right. A Hilbert curve does not have that. For a pseudo-Hilbert curve of order 1, if  the "direction" of a point in the bottom left corner is to the right, then for a curve of order 2, the direction would be up, 3 right, 4 up, and the limit would not exist, the same way you cannot define the limit of 1010101010101010 etc. If one were to apply something like a derivative test to a Hilbert curve it seems to me that the line from f(a) to f(a+h), as h goes to 0, would be something like an infinite spiral, the slope of that line would never converge to a constant value. In other words, it would be physically impossible to draw a "tangent" line. So the question arises, can one have a space filling curve with every point having a position AND a direction?

The proof that it's possible to map a 2-dimensional value to a 1-dimensional one allows us to conclude that it is possible to map any n-dimensional value to a 1-dimensional value.
Consider the following:
Let's assume an HC that allows us to map a 2-dimensional plane to a 1-dimensional line.
Now let's say that for each point in the HC, the x-coordinate of that point maps to another identical HC, which means another 2-dimensional plane.
We now have one input (our 1-dimensional line) generating 3 outputs (the y-coordinate of the original HC and the plane in the new HC)
Since we can do this recursively, all odd values of n are possible.
Further, let's say that both x and y coordinates of the original HC are mapped to new HC's.
By symmetry we can see that the result will be the same, thus by recursion all even values of n are possible.
Since all odd values of n and all even values of n are possible, all values of n are possible. (n e N)

Just to mention, another application of the space-filling curves is in computer graphics. When the computer is applying a texture to some surface the texture needs to be loaded from the memory pixel by pixel. This is quite a slow process so (as many of you know) there is the cache to help. There is a great probability that adjacent pixels in 2D texture will be processed consecutively (or in not so distant iteration). However, computer memory is linear and so are all the caches. Therefore the 2D texture is linearized using a space-filling curve (NVIDIA CUDA is using Z-curve) and stored in the memory. So pixels close to each other in 2D are close to each other in the memory and thus there is high chance that they will be loaded in the same cache line which boosts the performance of texturing.

The goal of mapping 2D space into 1D space such that points close in 2D are also close in 1D is exactly how GPU's accelerate texture fetches. Both CPU's and GPU's use caches to speed up calculations, because it is expected that if I request data at some location, I will most likely request data close to that location in the near future. Basically, when you ask for a few bytes, they store an entire section of the memory in anticipation that you will use it. Memory is of course just a long line of bytes. Textures, whether they are 2D or 3D, are slightly different. If I request a color from a texture at some 2D or 3D point, the same logic would mean that I would want to store an entire 2D or 3D chunk around that point in anticipation of the future. So in order to reuse the same caching mechanism that already works for 1D arrays, they use a curve, in this case, the Morton's Curve or Z-Curve. It is not as mathematically optimal as a Hilbert curve in terms of keeping nearby 2D points nearby in 1D, but it is extremely simple to compute from the 2D coordinate by just turning X and Y into binary, interleaving their bits, and then converting back into a single decimal location. And that is how basically every GPU provide a "2D" cache or "3D" cache optimized for textures.

A digital image is a 2D matrix...or maybe three 2D matrices in the case of a color image.  But when it's stored in memory, it's a long string of bytes.  By convention, it's usually the top leftmost pixel value, followed by the adjacent right pixel, and so on to the end of the row, and then it's the leftmost pixel on the second row, etc...Phylo Farnsworth's corn-rows.  Now there are cases when you want to repeatedly  manipulate the pixels in an image in one small region followed by the next.  Each operation can work with a center pixel along with all the neighboring pixels.    An example is bad pixel replacement, blurring/deblurring etc.   Depending on the pixel depth, it may be a series of bytes in little endian order,  BGR or RBG, etc.  Now since assembly code is going to manipulate an array in small flat chunks in a crowded cache and ultimately a limited number  of registers. what if you store the pixels of your image into main memory (or a file) using a reticulated-curve path instead of the left-to-right, top to bottom approach?    Has anyone tried optimizing image processing algorithms that way?

I know I'm late to the party here, but this video was making me think about whether Hilbert's curve was somehow a bijection from 1D space to 2D space. It's really interesting that any individual pseudo-Hilbert curve is injective, but that this property doesn't hold for the actual Hilbert curve (this is the secret sauce as to why it almost looks like you can define a bijection that "jumps" up a dimension - every individual step before the limit is injective, and you know that the final product will be surjective [that is, for any point in the 2D output space, you know you can find a corresponding point in the input space such that the Hilbert function would map the input point to that output point], but the injectivity is not preserved once you take the limit). An easy example of this is the point (1/2, 1/2), where there are multiple distinct input points which would map to that output.

OK, here's my problem with the space filling curve: For example, get all the continuous space between 0 and 4, now divide that space in half, and then in half again, and then again and again, all the way to infinity. Every single point between 0 and 4 in 1D continuous space should be accounted for, right? Well, wrong! because pi is there somewhere, and so is e, and phi, and the square root of 2, etc. Even though you have infinity divided 1 dimensional continuous space into 0 dimensional points, you still haven't accounted for all the space/points that actually exist in that region. This is proven as per Cantor's order of infinities. Similarly, with space filling curves, it's basically the same thing going on, except just with one extra dimension (and I'm pretty sure you can repeat the pattern for higher dimensional space). So for example with the Hilbert curve, the line is a fractal based on a tessellating square pattern, so it is dividing 2 dimensional continuous space into infinite lines following a pattern of right angles. Can such a pattern, taken to the limit of infinity, fully account for every single point that appears on the curve of a circle? or a natural logarithmic spiral? Or curves which cannot be defined by a polynomial series? I don't think so. Therefore, the Hilbert curve doesn't actually account for the complete infinity of continuous 2 dimensional space, it only accounts for those points which can be defined rationally, it cannot account for any irrational points within that space, because the very nature of its propagation through space is rational, and therefore even though you can take its limit to infinity it still will never be able to account for irrational points in the curvature of space, as would be found on the circumference of a perfect circle appearing within the infinite Hilbert curve. The Hilbert curve would NEVER FULLY account for every single point on the circumference of a perfect circle, it would only get closer and closer rational approximations as the limit goes towards infinity.

My small take: the only reason people think infinite maths is too abstract or philosophical to be useful is that it is often phrases as if these are theorems about infinite objects, e.g. infinitely-dense spaces, or infinitely-long lists of integers. It's a classic belief (that may or may not be wise) that we life in a finite world, or that only "God" is infinite and can understand infinity. This is a rather medieval way of thinking in my opinion, but it's still a strong intuition for many people. BUT if we rethink infinite maths not as positive statements about infinite things, but negative statements about finite things, then it becomes much more tangible.

For example, a simple theorem such as "the number of sets constructible from ZFC set theory is infinite" can be reinterpreted as "no matter how many sets you construct, we can construct more." The latter statement doesn't have any weird metaphysical baggage loaded. Likewise, in this video, the theorem "The Hilbert Curve is a well-defined functional curve that bijects the unit interval to the unit square" can be reinterpreted as "any improvements to your camera will cause pixel-position deviation at, at most, epsilon-pixel-widths." The latter statement is equivalent to the former, but can be expressed in a tangible way that makes no direct reference to abstract objects like curves or limits.

I like your video's and appreciate the effort you put into them.
However, this video is nonsense. :)

1) The method shown for extending the hilbert curve (add 3 copies, twist 2 around) does NOT preserve point positions. It confines all previous points to a 1/4th area and all but one points (0,0) will be out of place. This method basically adds more points to the ends of the curve.

2) For point preservation you need to extend the hilbert curve equally at every point. This means that you can only have point preservation if you extend it by 2 times on each side. You can't use hilbert curves to extend the resolution by an arbitrary amount while preserving positions. It has to be 2^2 and the extention has to be applied the same to every point on the curve to give this property.
So the new bits of curve must replace every point in the curve at that particular place and not simply extend the ends. This is what guarantees the points position to not change.

3) Now to the snake situation. If you replace every bit of the snake by a longer bit of snake (like is needed in the hilbert curve case) and you apply the same restriction of having to upp the length by 4 (2 on each side in the 2D view) then this will ALSO preserve position.

So this whole explanation of hilbert curve and snake curve is contrived and doesn't make any sense.

There may be other properties of the hilbert curve that makes it interesting, but what is shown in the video is not it.

Also fun way to convert a pixel co-ordinate to a spot on the Hilbert curve is to interleave the bits of the integer co-ordinates, that is if you have a 16x16 image you have two 4 bit co-ordinates with bits x3 x2 x1 x0, y3 y2 y1 y0 and you interleave them x3 y3 x2 y2 x1 y1 x0 y0.

GPUs actually do this to textures so that pixels that are close to together in space are close together in memory in both spatial directions which improves efficiency since computers fetch data from memory in chucks and if you need a pixel you're likely to need another pixel near it.

I was messing around with squares/cubes of higher order (up to 5 dimentions) and looked at properties of those cubes: Lattice points, Verticies and numbers dealing to those ones. I noted that lattice points are equal to two raised to the power of it's dimension (as pointed out in your fractal geometry video) but noticed a strange pattern for the vertices: 0, 1, 4, 12, 32, 80, 192. After further inspection and logic/reasoning, I figured out this "equation" for vertices: Vert(D) = (Vert(D-1)*2)+(Latt(D-1))D = the dimension of the hyper-cubeLatt = lattice points of specified dimentionVert = vertices of specified dimension This is because the difference between a hyper-cube and another hyper-cube of one higher dimension is that It appears as if the lower-dimension hyper-cube was duplicated and then the two were attached together. Thus you take the vertices from the lower dimention and times by two, and then add the lattice points because the connection between two hyper-cubes will connect a pair of lattice points. It isn't very complicated or hard to find out, but discovering it myself, alone, was worth sharing (I think)

It seems to me that the Hilbert curve never quite gets to the point (0.5, 0.5). It gets to (0.5, 0.5+an infinitesimal amount), and it gets to (0.5-an infinitesimal amount, 0.5-an infinitesimal amount) and (0.5+an infinitesimal amount, 0.5-an infinitesimal amount). Those three points it does hit are at 1/2, 1/6, and 5/6 of the way along the Hilbert curve, respectively. But at no point does it ever hit 0.5, 0.5 exactly. Nor indeed does it hit any point between (0.5, 0) and (0.5, 0.5). And the same holds true for all of the dyadic rational points: It never hits (0.25, 0.25), (0.75, 0.25), etc., nor any of the points on the line segment from (0, 0.25) to (0.25, 0.25), etc. It only hits the points off of these line segments by an infinitesimal amount.

I get how it becomes a 2-dimensional thing, and how it can hit all the pixels in a finite square and any finite resolution, but it doesn't seem to hit every single point within that square. Granted, the points it misses are only an infinitesimal proportion of the total points, but those points don't seem to correspond to a specific point on the Hilbert curve.

From Wikipedia: "Cantor's 1874 Crelle paper was the first to invoke the notion of a 1-to-1 correspondence, though he did not use that phrase. He then began looking for a 1-to-1 correspondence between the points of the unit square and the points of a unit line segment. In an 1877 letter to Richard Dedekind, Cantor proved a far stronger result: for any positive integer n, there exists a 1-to-1 correspondence between the points on the unit line segment and all of the points in an n-dimensional space. About this discovery Cantor wrote to Dedekind: "Je le vois, mais je ne le crois pas!" ("I see it, but I don't believe it!")."

An important point is demonstrated at 13:05. The Pseudo-Hilbert curves are injective (meaning that any two points on the line get mapped to different points on the square), but the true Hilbert curve isn't (meaning you can find a pair of points on the line that get mapped to the same point on the square). Look at the bottom two points in the animation; they approach each other as we get to higher and higher orders of Pseudo-Hilbert curve, and will collide once we take the limit.

I am sure that there are infinitely many points in the square that won't be filled by a Hilbert curve. Let's take for example the middle point and look at the tiled version of the square. If you have 2 by 2 tiles and you fill the square with a level one pseudo Hilbert curve, the curve will never reach the corners of the tiles. It can't reach the corners at any pseudo Hilbert curve, since it will allways go through each tile once, and when it does it goes right through the center of the tile. If you Splitt Up tiles to fill them with higher level Hilbert curves the courve would get closer to the corners, but will never go through a corner of a tile.

That means if you would use a space filling Hilbert curve to fill a square it wouldn't get to the corners of the square. So if you would copy this square to a 2 by 2 grid, just like you did with the pseudo Hilbert curve all the corners of the tiles would never be reached by the curve.

4:40 an explanation that I use:
an order 1 Hilbert approximation (repeat your explanation for that here)
the next order up, copy the current order 4 times and arrange them in a square. then rotate the two bottom curves, pushing /their/ bottoms away from each-other, and connect those 4 parts at their ends with the shortest 3 lines.
EDIT: now, if you iterate this infinitely, what you get is a set of points that map onto a line, where being near each-other in 2d space maps VERY closely to being near each-other on the line.
EDIT 2: also note since the Hilbert curve is reflectively similar, though it may be easier for you to program under the flip intuition, it might actually be worse for humans to understand in some cases.

Well-defined and continuous are obvious because of uniform convergence (points all move in a certain "square" which gets smaller and whose size depends only on n)

To prove space filling, I'd suggest :
Notice L_n the lattice of all points which are corner for the nth curve f_n.
Now let x be a point of the square. There is a sequence a_n of points such that a_n is in L_n and which approaches x (this is more or less the dyadic developpement). Write a_n = f_n(u_n), with u_n between 0 and 1 (corners are obviously in the image). Extract a subsequence of u_n, notated u_{p(n)}, which converges to a certain l. Now f_{p(n)}(u_{p(n)}) approaches x and using uniform convergence you deduce that f(l)=x, so that f is indeed space filling.

Those three things were easier to prove than I thought they would be. In summary:

1. Since the 4 quadrants of any PHC are equal in length (preemptively add connecting tails to the first and last to make this work), increasing the order of the PHC won't change the quadrant of a mapping in it. Since each quadrant of a PHC of order higher than 1 is another PHC, this continues, bounding the mapping to a geometrically smaller and smaller space as the order increases.

2. One can bound an arbitrarily nearby point to an arbitrarily nearby (and small) sub-quadrant using the above.

3. Write input numbers (lengths) in base 4. Every number now maps to a specific set of infinite subdivisions of sub-quadrants, and every set of subdivisions of sub-quadrants has a specific input number, identifiable directly by its digits; and these uncountably infinite sub-quadrants fill the block. Output coordinates can be written in base 2 to show the correspondence between any point in the block and it's associated series of sub-divisions.

One could make a two-way mapping solely out of the digits, though one would need to know all digits preceding a given digit to correctly associate the digit in the HC-space to the digit in the block-space, due to the rotations of the first and fourth quadrants of every PHC.

Feel free to point out any major oversights on my part. I'm bad at rigour.

I don't think the word curve is misused at all, I actually understand it more as a space filling curve

For a moment I thought I saw a flaw in the space "filling" curve argument because of the asymptotic nature of the function at the divides of the quadrants. I thought that points surrounding the asymptotes get infinitely close to touching the quadrant boundaries, but never actually collide; while that is true for finite curves, infinite curves probably do join at the asymptotes eventually, even if it's only in a limit sense.

Then, I thought that would break the function property of the curve. One (two dimensional) point has two outputs! Here I am breaking a century's worth of genius mathematicians' hard work.

It's too bad that two-D space is the output, and points on the number-line are the inputs. It is the listener's job to decipher the line. It's perfectly fine for two points on the number-line to both output to the same two-D point. It's just like x^2 hitting 4 both at -2 and 2. It's just like the trig functions, etc...

This was fun for me to work out that the function is indeed a function because it is a little bit more abstracted than what the normal way of quickly assessing a curve's functionality. You can't just do a vertical line test, or some form of a planar test. It was just a very pure form of "an output can have multiple inputs, but an input can only have one output."

I didn't have this fun logic moment the first time you uploaded this, so I appreciate the re-upload.
